awd_titl_txt: EAGER/SusChEM/Collaborative Research: Feasibility of Molten Oxide Inductolysis for Metal Alloy Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) Sustainable Chemistry, Engineering, and
Materials (SusChEM) Collaborative Research project will allow for experiments to demonstrate the feasibility of Molten Oxide Inductolysis, a new concept that holds the promise to reduce energy consumption, greenhouse gas emissions and the capital investment required to process metal alloys. This concept relies on the use of electricity (derived from renewable sources) to convert various oxide ore feedstock to metal, allowing for greater flexibility on the raw materials to be used for alloy production. With this concept, it may be possible to use lower grade (i.e. cheaper) feedstock with comparable product quality. This enhanced flexibility, coupled with the potential to operate with less harmful emissions, could impact the return of metal manufacturing in the United States.

This project combines electrolysis with inductive heating to eliminate the dependence on resistive heating during processing of high temperature master alloys.  The underlying premise is that it will be possible to decouple the heat-generation processes from the electrolysis process through the use of induction heating. The goal is to balance the energy such that the energy required for the oxide decomposition would be derived from the electrochemical potential difference while induction would provide the other energy needs such as melting and superheating. The proposed work will seek to demonstrate an experimental proof-of-concept for this innovation using a model laboratory reactor system. Future work will address the fundamentals of the process-structure relationships, the development of a comprehensive electrochemical and thermal process model as well as a path to scale-up for Molten Oxide Inductolysis.

por.por_cntn:
Molten Oxide Electrolysis (MOE) is a technology that involves the direct production of metal from a molten mixture of oxides. The advantages of this technique are: (1) the direct use of raw ore feedstock, (2) the production of a liquid metal product, and (3) the reduction of CO2 emissions required per ton of metal produced. In the context of greenhouse gas (GHG) emission mitigation, the steelmaking industry has shown support in bring such green technologies to realization. With more than a billion tons of materials produced yearly, the metal industry is the largest contributor to industrial CO2 emissions in developed countries.

This technology relies on the self-heated reactor concept where there is a subtle balance between the heat generated by the current flow in the reactor to that needed to maintain the reactor, reactants, and products at the desired reaction temperature. Instead of burning carbon to generate CO2 and heat to keep the raw stock and product molten, we use inductive heating using electricity generated hydrothermally to limit greenhouse gas generation. The electrolysis of iron oxide has paved the way to decouple direct CO2 generation from the production of metal by using electrons as the reducing agent with the cogeneration of oxygen as the anodic by-product. However, many challenges are foreseen when applying the current paradigm to other metals or alloys with melting point higher than 1500°C.

This report documents activities to demonstrate that the MOI technique is feasible in the production of iron. Specifically, we investigated if the presence of high frequency magnetic fields associated with induction heating would forbid the application of electrolysis for the production of iron. In this study, we have demonstrated that it is indeed possible to (1) maintain a stable temperature of operation with the induction system during electrolysis, and (2) measure current and potential during controlled electrolysis for over an hour and (3) used pulse electrolysis techniques to define system performance and prove that the presence of the high frequency magnetic fields from induction heating does not inhibit the MOE process.
